slides.title: Introduction to Psychology

content.subtitle: Understanding the Science of Mind and Behavior

slides.notes: Welcome students to this introductory psychology presentation. Psychology is one of the most popular academic subjects because it helps us understand ourselves and others.

slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.notes: By the end of this presentation, learners should be able to meet all four objectives. These form the foundation for deeper study in psychology.

slides.title: What is Psychology?
slides.notes: Psychology comes from Greek: psyche (mind/soul) + logos (study). It became a formal science in 1879 when Wilhelm Wundt established the first psychology laboratory in Leipzig, Germany.

slides.title: Major Perspectives
slides.notes: Psychology has evolved through several major schools of thought. Each perspective offers unique insights into human behavior and mental processes.

slides.title: Behavioral vs Cognitive
slides.notes: Behaviorism dominated the early 20th century, while the cognitive revolution began in the 1950s. Today, cognitive-behavioral approaches combine both perspectives in therapy.

slides.title: Additional Perspectives
slides.notes: Modern psychologists often take an eclectic approach, drawing from multiple perspectives. The biopsychosocial model is particularly influential in health psychology.

slides.title: The Biopsychosocial Model
slides.notes: George Engel proposed this model in 1977. It recognizes that health and behavior result from the complex interaction of biological, psychological, and social factors.

slides.title: Fundamental Concepts

content.subtitle: Core principles every student should know

slides.notes: These foundational concepts appear throughout psychology courses and are essential for understanding more advanced topics.

slides.title: Types of Conditioning
slides.notes: Classical conditioning: neutral stimulus becomes associated with unconditioned stimulus. Operant conditioning: behavior is strengthened or weakened by its consequences.

slides.title: Memory Systems
slides.notes: The Atkinson-Shiffrin model describes these three memory stores. Working memory (Baddeley) expanded on short-term memory to include manipulation of information.

slides.title: Landmark Studies
slides.notes: These classic studies are frequently cited and have profoundly influenced our understanding of human behavior. Some also raised important ethical questions.

slides.title: Classic Experiments
slides.notes: These studies revealed surprising aspects of human nature. Milgram showed ordinary people could inflict apparent harm when instructed by authority figures. Many of these studies led to improved ethical guidelines in research.

slides.title: Words of Wisdom

content.text: The greatest discovery of my generation is that human beings can alter their lives by altering their attitudes of mind.
content.attribution: William James, Father of American Psychology

slides.notes: William James (1842-1910) established the first American psychology laboratory at Harvard. His pragmatic approach emphasized the practical applications of psychology.

slides.title: Applications & Summary
slides.notes: Psychology is not just academic theory - it has practical applications that affect everyday life across many domains.

slides.title: Psychology in Action
slides.notes: Psychology graduates work in diverse fields. Clinical psychology is the largest specialty, but I/O psychology and health psychology are rapidly growing areas.

slides.title: Key Takeaways
slides.notes: Review the learning objectives from the beginning. Psychology provides tools for understanding ourselves and others, with both theoretical and practical value.
